Precisely.  It's a tool used in the configuration of the kernel packet filtering.
rob_P: how is it not service ?
nomand777: sudo iptables -F ok .. now i again want to start iptables then ?
A service implies a process that runs... iptables is not, "running" but gets called during the initial configuration of the kernel packet filtering mechanism.
Once iptables establishes the ruleset, it is not, "running."  Understand?
rob_P: ok, so its mean it is not daemon, even in cEntos ?
Yes.  Even in CentOS.
